qas.question: What does mapping clusters disentangle ancestry from?
Hammer and others recently aimed to test what claim about how closely related present-day Jews are to what group?
What shifted depending on the locus investigated?

answers.text: the degree of genetic similarity among Jews

qas.question: What was suggested the reason for the degree of genetic shift among Jews was the result of?

answers.text: natural selection acting on particular loci

qas.question: What chromosome was focused on to circumvent some of the complications associated with selection?

context: Abu el-Haj argues that genomics and the mapping of lineages and clusters liberates "the new racial science from the older one by disentangling ancestry from <a0_0>culture<a0_0/> and capacity."[citation needed] As an example, she refers to recent work by Hammer et al., which aimed to test the claim that present-day Jews are more closely related to one another than to <a1_0>neighbouring non-Jewish populations<a1_0/>. Hammer et al. found that <a2_0>the degree of genetic similarity among Jews<a2_0/> shifted depending on the locus investigated, and suggested that this was the result of <a3_0>natural selection acting on particular loci<a3_0/>. They focused on the non-recombining <a4_0>Y<a4_0/>-chromosome to "circumvent some of the complications associated with selection".
